div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,730] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, APRIL 10, 1907. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with the Orient Railways Express Service for VIENNA, BERLIN, PARIS & LONDON.
The S. S. Osmanieh will resume her express sailings on May 8.

PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.–The fast steamers Prince Abbas and Assouan leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina, continuing in alternate weeks to Larnaca (Cyprus).

SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.–The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express serice to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.–Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden
For further information refer to Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez, or to THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIKA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: EGYPT OF THE FUTURE
div.p: Delusions are less dangerous to individuals than to political parties. The former can be interred in asylums or banded over to the care of expert hirelings or necessitous relatives, but parties, even in Egypt, (where we are assured by "Al Watan" that parties do not exist) can hardly be put under lock and key or confined in their dwellings pending medical evidence of their restoration to sanity. No delusion is, in any case, more harmful to the genus politician than that which simulates the jovial and amioable stage of drunkenness and leads the sufferer to repose the most implicit faith in the assurances of his neighbours that he is the host of good fellows, and the man of all men whom they are most desirous to benefit. In private life such assurances are accepted with caution by the sober-minded individual who dislikes the prospect of having to lend five pounds to his interested friends, but the enthusiast—especially when alcohol has added warmth to his enthusiasm—is likely to find himself lying in the kennol with broken head and empty pockets or to discover All too late that he has advanoed considerable sums on worthless securities. But when political parties pin their faith on the benevolence ot

the neighbours of their country they ran the risk of involving not mearly themselves but their fatherland in an utter end general discomfiture more especially when their ooontry is temptingly rich end their fellow citizens are not hardened in the school of war or political strife.

The Egyptian Nationalist*-or rather that section which acknowledges Mustapha. Pasha Kamel as its chief—appears to us to be suffering at present from this very delusion. In spokesmen imagine that when Great Britain has been persuaded, or compelled to withdraw the troops from Egypt, to exercise no farther control on the Goverument of the country and to bestow free Parliamentary institutions on the Egyptian people as a parting gift, Egypt will become at once the cynosure of the admiring eyes of an enthusiastic Europe. An educated people will receive foreign visitors with open arms, a highly trained civil service of Moslem Egyptian—all no doubt in possession of diplomas won at the new University— will aid the cultivator to pick three kantarsof cotton where one grew before and—though this conclusion is publicly suppressed—X.Y. Pasha and Blank Dash Bey will gloriously direct the Foreign or the internal policy of a new land of Cockayne.

Fortunately for this section of our patriots they are not likely to be in a position to test the soundness of their predictions, for we believe that the occupation will continue undisturbed by their clamours. But they are doing a considerable amount of harm by spreading a belief in the certainty of a golden age following the evacuation of the country by British troops and officials, and thereby encouraging the younger members of the educated class of Egyptians to form an exaggerated opinion of the strength of an independent Egypt. Let us assume that one fine day the great British Public in one of its intermittent anti-imperial reactions was led to believe that Blank Pasha and Dash Bey were capable of assisting the ruler of the day at Abdin to govern Egypt without foreign advice and assistance and took the predictions of "the Lews" literally. Let us suppose that the British Garrison withdrew, the British Agent at Kasr el Donbara became simply and solely the Minister of one of the many foreign Powers represented at Cairo, frhat would bo the probable consequences of the withdrawal.

We will assume Mustapha Pasha Kamel's high opinion of the virtues and talents of his countrymen and their fitness for self-government to be justified. It is a low assumption, but we are not now concerned with that issue, and will allow it to pass. Is it conceivable that the new Egypt would always be surrounded by friendly and pacific neighbours!

Some of our Nationalist prophets would solve the difficulty by an "arrangement" with England whereby the Egyptians after getting rid of the occupation would benefit by the moral protection generously accorded them by the great-sea-power. There, is a Celtic title which tells of a family who sought the protection of a chief of a powerful sect in the days of its weakness. After many years the heads of the family declared themselves able to stand alone and sent the representatives of the chief packing. The chief, who was an easy going fellow enough, announced that he would accept the fait accompli, whereupon the now independent clan sent him a polite message assuring him of their high consideration and hoping that he would take the sympathetic interest in their welfare that had so honourable distinguished him in the past. Shortly afterwards a band of brigands descended upon be lands of the seceders and inflicted the worst usage upon its occupants. In despair they appealed to the generous instincts of the easy going chief, who replied in a courteous let or that while his heart bled for them he ready could not undertake to bleed his people and his country on their behalf. The fable applies to the case of Egypt, let Great Britain once evacuate an Egypt "ripe for independence" and it will not be easy to persuade the British public to sacrifice blood and treasure on behalf of an alien people.

Others assume that it would be a simple matter to persuade the great Powers to guarantee the neutrality of Egypt. We doubt it—it takes six powers to make a "Concert" and then the performers must keep time. Moreover the powers would demand a "quid pro quo" and it is easy to imagine a state of affairs in which the British Occupation had been replaced by some form of international control—a possibility to which even Mr. Wilfred Scawen Blunt prefers the status quo. Were Egypt inhabited by a race which considered the defence of the country the noblest duty of a citizen, which would die in heaps for an ideal, which regarded a wide patriotism as the hallmark of every good citizen whatever his race and creed, in a word were the Egyptians Japanese, a race permeated by the deeds of a warlike bit disciplined and self sacrificing aristocracy, Egypt would never have known a foreign occupation. But as things are, the greatest admirer of the Egyptian people, the warmest champion of Egyptian independence; cannot but admit with sorrow that the evacuation of Egypt by Great Britain would deprive the country of its one efficient bulwark against foreign conquest and spoliation, unless he is blinded by vanity or ignorant of the Bismarckean dictum that in the last resort blood and iron, not speeches or Parliamentary majorities, decide the fate of nations.

div.head: Hashish Seizure
div.p: During last yoar 15,345 kilos of hashish were seized and confiscated.

div.head: Water at Mecca.
div.p: Subscriptions for the installation of water Mecca now amount to LE. 29,759.15.

div.head: Brindiel Mall.
div.p: The mail from Brindisi via Port Said will be distributed at Alexandria at 4.30 p m. today.

div.head: Foundling Hospital.
div.p: Out of a total of 76 children admitted into the Foundling Hospital at Cairo during the past year no less than 64 died.

div.head: The Cairo Mussum.
div.p: The great work of the compilation of the catalogue of the Cairo Museum will probably be completed in three years' time and that of printing in six years. The total number of volumes published since 1901 is fifteen. Nine new volumes appeared during last year.

div.head: Run Over by a Tram.
div.p: A soldier of the Egyptian army was killed in Cairo this morning through dismounting from the wrong side of a tramcar, while a tram running in the opposite direction was passing. Not noticing the second tram, the unfortunate soldier stopped on to the line and was run over

div.head: New Mex Bollero.
div.p: As a result of the adjudication held in the office of the Inspector of Irrigation 3rd Circle, Alexandria, on 29th February, the supply of four new Galloway Type boilers for the Government Pumping Station at Mex has been entrusted to Messrs. Edwin Dunks & Co. of Oldbury, Birmingham, for the sum of Lst. 1820.

div.head: Sinai and Patrn.
div.p: We have received a copy of the recently published journals of Miss Hornby giving on account of her journeys to Sinai and Petra in 1899 and 1901. They contain, a pleasant and unsophisticated diary of each day's happenings and should be a useful book to tourists from Egypt who contemplate visiting by way of Suez the Sinaitic Peninsula and the wonderful ruins of Petra. Messrs. James Nisbet and Co., Ltd., of 21 Borners-street, London, are the publishers. The price of the book, which is illustrated with some charming coloured plates, is 6s.

div.head: Provincial Fire
div.p: Our Damanhour correspondent reports a serious outbreak of fire at Kouboor Amara in the Deligat markaz, on Monday morning, which lasted 65 hours. The fire brigade from Delingat was called out and at midnight an engine was sent by special train from Damanhour. One child was burnt to dea h and two children soriou-ly injured,
The upsetting of a petroleum lamp in a carpenter's store caused a serious fire at Mehalla Kobra. Fourteen houses were destroyed and the damage is estimated at LE. 14,000. -.

div.head: An Example from Algeria.
div.p: The idea of the English Government attempting to encourage art by founding an institution of English artists in Egypt is beyond the reach of tje wildest imagination. Yet the French authorities are about to establish a species of Villa Medicis in Algeria, for the education of French artists in that colony. The Governor of Algeria has just secured for this purpose a Moorish house with a large garden. The first "titulaires" of the "bourses de voyage" in Algeria will be nominated in Paris on the 15th inst. by a committee of which the head is the Keeper of the Luxembourg.

div.head: Creek Easter
div.p: Although our Easter occured on the 31st ulto. in the Eastern Church, adhering to the old style of the calendar, Easter falls this year five weeks after ours on the day called in the Julian calendar April 22nd, but in the Gregorian May 8th. Last year it occurred on tho same real day by both calendars, the day reckoned April 2nd in the East being the same as that called April 15th in the West, The reason of the difference is that this year our paschal (the calendar, not the actual full moon was on March 27th, whereas the Julian style, making the dates thirteen days earlier, has to call the preceding full moon the paschal one, as being the next after March 21st.

div.head: Inquest on Barablno.
div.p: The adjourned inquest on the late Luigi Barabino, a Maltese, was held yesterday morning at the British Consulate before Mr A DJ Alban, his Britannic Majesty's Consul. The deceased's sister-in-law was the first witness, and Dr. Munson also gave evidence. An officer and a school teacher who hail seen the deceased throw himself under the train at Koubbch on Good Friday last at 7.20 a.m. were also called as witnesses, as was the driver of the train. After Mr Alban had summed up, the jury, without retiring, brought a verdict of suicide while temporarily insane. The deceased was 50 years old, and a compositor in the State Railway printing department.

div.head:
THE ASSYR AT SUEZ
TURKISH TROOPS MUTINOUS
div.p: (From our own Correspondent)
Suez, Tuesday.

The Turkish troopship Assyr arrived al Suez yesterday from Hodeidah, and it is stated that while on the point of leaving that port, 400 more men of the garrison embarked by force, and the total number of men now on board exceed 1000.

The vessel was supposed to land the troops at Akaba, and from there they would have to 1 find their way to their country, but the soldiers compelled the Captain of the Assyr to bring them to Suez, and on arrival hero a mutiny broke out as usual, the men insisting on entering tho Canal at once.

However, owing to tho ship having no money to pay the Canal dues, the Egyptian Government, as previously, will hove to pay them in order to get rid of such dangerous visitors, and it is hoped arrangements will be made for the ship to enter this afternoon.
The state on board is deplorable, and the overcrowding remarkable. The Captain of the ship does not know the exact number of troops he carries.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive has left Montazah for his estates at Mariout.
The official date of his Highness' departure for the season to Alexandria is Saturday the 27th inst, at 7.30 in the moniing. The reception at Abdin Palace will take place on tho 25th of April

The Khedive, most willing to give a proof of his high benevolence to Mrs. Henrietta Homik, surgical dentist of Vienna University, has kindly allowed her to keep the title of Surgical Dentist of the Court. We congratulate the lady.

div.head: PICTURE EXHIBITION IN CAIRO
div.p: Mr. O. W. Sturgo is exhibiting a very interesting series of water colour drawings at tho Savoy this week, the results of his winter's work in Egypt. His colouring is distinctly clear and transparent, and many of his sketches are particularly happy in composition and expression. He has drawn inspiration on many occasion from the Pyramids, and has done nothing finer that the view entitled "A Hot Day" which was taken from below the Sphinx temple. Another view, equally good, is taken from the Arab cemetery beyond the Pyramids, and again there are the mighty tops of the two monuments at Ghizeh appearing from out the rolling mists, and yet another time they figure in sombre mans against the fading light of sunset. Some of Mr: Sturgo's river sketches are quite beautiful, especially that entitled 'A Grey Morning," and another showing a Coptic convent surmounting the pink touched hills and with a very misty background. There is a delightful glimpse of distant Cairo taken from the Pyramid road, the vivid green crops, and the flat bridge across the waters in the foreground being details familiar to and beloved by most of us. Luxor and Assouan have provided materials for Mr. Sturge's facile brush, and he has two fine views of Koin Ombo, and some beautiful ones taken in the Fayourn, one a soft translucent stretch of green water with a few scattered palms and a very misty background; and another taken at sunset, a minaret and adjoining buildings looming purple against the sky and casting shadows, in the reflecting river.

Mr. Sturge's sketches are all the more valuable from their great local interest. They mostly represent views well-known to all of ' us, and will surely be in request by those who wish to carry away momentoes of this and of gorgeous colouring.
These pictures of Mr. Sturge will remain on view at the Savoy throughout the present

div.head: INNISKILLING FUSILIER DROWNED
div.p: A sad boating fatality occurred shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the vicinity of the Ghizeh Bridge. It appears that a party of seven of 2nd Bn. Inniskilling fusiliers left Kasr-el-Nil Barracks about two o'clock for a row up the river, none of the party being expert oar-men. The bridge was reached without mishap, but about 4.30 pm when on the return journey and in the vicinity of the Creek, Bandsman Sweeney, who had been standing up, was, by a swerve of the boat, thrown into the river. Two of his comrades, Privates Maddocks and Gooding promptly dived after him, but he disappeared beneath the surface and was not seon to rise again. A strong current was running and the two comrades who had acted so promptly were only got into the boat after some difficulty and in an exhausted state Search is being made for the body, which had not been recovered last evening. The unfortunate man was about 30 years ofa ge, and was a prominent member of the hand, being an excellent side-drummer.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The mail steamship Prince Abbas will leave Alexandria at 4 p.m. on Saturday and Port Said at 4 p.m. on Sunday for Jaffa, Caiffa, Beyrouth, Tripoli, Mersina, Alexandretta, Larnaca. and Limsassol (optional)
The Mobs liner Slones passed Holyhead yesterday bound for Liverpool

div.head: ARABIC AND ENGLISH TEACHING
div.p: The following answers were given to questions asked in the House of Commons on this 22nd March

Mr. John Robertson.—To ask tho Secretary of State for Foreign Afiairs, what is the number of subject taught in Arabic and English respectively in the Egyptian primary and secondary schools, higher or technical schools, and professional colleges respectively.
Sir Edward Grey.— I will ask for the information requested. Which can no doubt be obtained.

div.head: FREE EDUCATION.
div.p: Mr. John Robertson.— To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he will instruct the British Agent in Egypt to advise the more rapid development of the State machinery for training of teacher for the elementary schools (kuttabs) with a view to the establishment in Egypt of a system of free and compulsory education in such school for both sexes.

Sir Edward Grey. — The honourable Member will see from Lord Cromer's Report for the year 1906, which will shortly be published, that the Egyptian Government arc fully alive to the importance of this question, and that no instructions of the kind suggested are requited to call attention to it.

div.head: BUILDING IN CAIRO.
div.p: Mr. John Rodkrtson.—'To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether, where building operations are proceeding in Cairo, the footways aud even thoroughfares up to the middle of the road are rendered impassable for months together by accumulations of building material .and debris ; whether the footways and portions of roadways so encumbered are rented by the Tanzim Department to building contractors; and whether he will ad rise tho Egyptian Oournmcntto discontinue a practice to which many street accidont* are attributable.
Sir Edward Grey.— I have no information on the subject. Tho matter is ono of admin­istrative detail which must be left to the officials on tho spot, who can investigate th* circumstances.

div.head: CRIMINAL ASSIZE COURTS.
div.p: Mb. John Robertson.— Toask tho Secre­tary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether, see­ing that tho procedure preliminary and in­cidental to trial in the recently constituted Criminal Courts of Assize in Egypt, which consist _of throe judges 'from whose decision there is no apical save on points of Law, though thus far satisfactory on tho score of expedition, does not afford sufficient, safeguard against a miscarriage of justice ; and, seeing that the marked tendency of European public | opinion is in favour of granting an appeal upon ! tho facts in all sorious criminal cases, will hs ! advise tho Egyptian Government to restore tho right of appeal, such appeal to involve in every case a rehearing.

.Sir Edward Grey.— The matter is prim­arily one for tho decision of -the Egyptian Government in the first instance, and tho nftw system" appears to be working satisfactorily. It would also probably bo desirablo to sottlo the question of criminal appeals at home, which has given riso to some controversy, before giving advice elsewhere.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT
div.p: RESIGNATION OF LOCAL DIRECTORS

We are authorisied to state that Crookshank Pasha and Maltre Carton de Wiart resigned their positions of directors of the Corporation of Western Egypt, Ltd. on March 31 owing to a decision of the London board of directors suppressing the post of general manager in Egypt until recently held by Mr. Beckett and taking over the entire managmenet of the Corporation work in the Oasis into their own hands.
Crookshank Pasha and Maitre Carton de Wiart are the only members of the local board of directors Johnson Pasha not having yet joined the board as he is still connected with the Egyptian Governemnt

Mr. Milne, director of the Agricultural Department, Mr. Spencer, resident engineer, and Mr. Garseed, director of the chemcial service at the lead quarteres of the Corporation in the Oasis of Khargeh, have resigned their positions

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY LTD
div.p: We learn from a reliable source that Mr. Sreville has successfully carried through the iale of the large estate of the New Egyptian Company, Ltd at Motaana, consisting of some 1,457 feddaus

div.head: ANGLO-BELGIAN COMPANY OF EGYPT
div.p: This company has purchased property at Bab-el-Loak, Cairo, near the terminus of the Helouan Railway, comprising 800 square metres, and a contract has been enetered into for the sale of this land at a profit. Another parcel of land bought by the company consists of 1,670 square metres opposite the Cairo Museum of Antiquities. Several officers for the purchase of this property from the company have been refused, but negotiations are, it is statel, proceeding at the present time for the sale of the same at a price which would show the company a considerable profit.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID
div.p: departure of our roval visitors.
(From our own Correspondent.)

div.head: Port Said, Tuesday.
div.p: T.R H. the Duke and Duchess of Connaught and Princess Patricia arrived here at 8 p.m. yesterday by a special train from Cairo. Their, Royal Highnesses were met at the station by the Governor, Mr. D. A Cameron C B., H.B M's Consul, Scbalch Bey. Commandant of Police, Mr. Damount, Principal Agent of the Canal Co., Mr. Geo. Royle and others. The Royal party drove direct to the Canal Company's landing stage escorted by mounted police, and embarked on the P. and O. S.S. Caledonia.

The Japanese battleship Tsukuba and the cruiser Chitose, which came out of the Canal about 2.80 p.m., together with H.M.8 Minerva, which arrived here at 7 am from Alexandria, made a pretty sight with their display of bunt­ing. When the Duke stepped on board the Caledonia, bis flag was hoisted on the inid-ship mast, and the band on the Japanese battleship played "God save the King."
Lord and Lady Meath also loft by tho Caledonia, which sailed at 6 p m

div.head: THE COLLIER'S STRIKE.
div.p: Coaling operations Sunday and yesterday were conducted by the ships own crews, but: to-day three or four ships have been coaled by the Arabs, who are slowly returning to their senses. To-day some two or three hundred have returned to work, and the remainder are expect to follow during the next few days, though at present they are standing fast to their demands.

div.head: FOOTBALL MATCH.
div.p: On Saturday afternoon a very fast and interesting rugby match was played between the Port Said Football Club and a team picked from ships in the harbour, when there was a very large attendance. The opening stages of the first half were in favour of the ships, but the club soon assumed the aggressive. Williams made a brilliant run nearly half the length of the field, but his effort was nullified through non-support. Port Said took matters into their ' own hands ; their forwards heeling olean and the halves getting the ball away to tbo backs, |:some fine rounds of passing wore witnessed. De Rougcmont had very hard lines in nut dropping a goal. From a scrum on the 25, over forwards heeled out, Field, Wallice, and Jones bandied before Williams received, the latter player getting home with a very fine try amid cheers from the club supporters. King failed at the kick for goal.

Just before half time the ships pressed hard and Port Said had a very anxious time : time after time they crossed the line, but man and ball were held up. De Rongemont got away and play was taken back to midfield when time was called.

Play had not long been resumed before Williams added another 4 points by dropping a very neat goal, thus giving his side a lead of 7 points. Arthur Jones made a number of smart bursts; once he got away he passed everybody, but unfortunately lost the ball when he had a clear field. The play of the ships, which up to this moment bad been of a desultory character, brightened up considerably and a superb effort on the part of the forwards nearly ended in a try. The pace which up to now had been very fast began to tell on those out of training, and the club had little diffi­culty in taking play into the ships territory. From a line out King walked over with another try and placed, the ball between the uprights ; the same player took the goal kick, but failed to add any points.

Port Said continued to press until time was called, at the close of the match a call for "Three cheers for the ships" was loudly responded to by both players and spectators. Port Said were the better team and fully merited their victory

div.head: A REMARKABLE FORECAST
div.p: One of the most interesting questions is as to who is to be the successor of Lord Cromer His Lordship's remark in his Report that "in the course of that short period during which, possibly, I ma^ltill be connected with Egyptian affairs" has again set the quidnurei of Egypt soleotiug likely raon to whom tho succession should fall Among the most interest­ing announcements that wo have met with h on this subject is that which is contained in yesterday's issue of "La Reforme." That news- i paper stated as follows:-

"Some friends of Mr. Mitchell Innea having « heard it said that Lord Cromer might retire, i have immediately thought? fit to put.forward ( this eminent and very distinguished offioial as ( a candidate. They have thought that con | sidering the difficulty of finding a position , fitted for the talents of Mr. Mitchell Inues it t would bo easier to raise him at one bound j to the highest rank. It is a very good idea and will be received with the success that it merits ] in all the circles where affairs and mon are t considered from a Serious point of view.
This remarkable piece of information will be received with great interest in Cairo, where the capacity of Mr. Mitchell Innes is well known

div.head: THE PLAGUE
div.p: During the week ended last Monday there were 57 cases of plague in Egypt, 21 of which occurred,at Nag Hamadt (Keneli), 10 at 8a- ■ molout Minieh), 5 at Deshneh (Keneh), 4 at E»neh (Keneh), 7 at Deirout (AasioutL 2 at Alexandria, Assiout," Akhmin (Guirgueh), and Keneh,, and 1 at Bcba (Beni-Soucf), and Beni Mazar (Minieh). During the same week 39 dniths were reportod, 9 case* were cured, and on Monday 38 cases remained under treatment. From the 1st January to 8th April there have been In all 373 oases of plague.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE
div.p: M. FERAUDY's FAREWELL

M. de Flmndy brought hi* tourntfe to a mo»t successful conclusion last night with "L'Avare ' and he and his company came in for a big ovatiodj without it being necessary to adopt any of Brichinteau's methods'

There was plenty of life about 'TAvare"; with only a few exceptions, M ' do f-Vraudy's company vory properly entered into tbo fun of the -thing, and, very properly left the audience to ponder in tbo entr'actes (while the curtain was up they were too busy laugh­ing) overihe underlying tragedy,which pervades the whole buffoonery, yet without once pene­trating it. Needless to say M de Fi-raudy was i delight from first to last. True, he was ofteu t little uncertain of his lines but this was imply compensated by the rollicking excellence )f his acting. Mme. Marie-Laure was well cast fur Fnsiue and pleased us mightily by her remarkably pure diction. Por the same reason *e should have liked to see M. Goumac in a arger part than La Flfcche. M. Sivgrin also leserves praise for a very cnorgetic and at :raotivo "Valfcre". M Bourdel's "ChSante" was air, but so hurried that a good many points vere missed. Mile. Maia fulfilled require- nents as "Mariana", but as "Elise" Mile Van Doren looked bored and was inclined to crumble through her part. We should not brget a satisfactory piece of work by M. Joury as Maltre Jacques.

"L'Avare" was preceded by M. Jules Cla­ude's "Monseigneur on Vacances" very neatly ind delicately acted by M de Ftfraudy and lime. Marie-Laure with a little assistance by Ulle. Dauville. Being at the fag end of the eason, it was appropriate to the "land of laradox" that the curtain should be dropped md raisod on an ompty stage in tho most imateur fashion, leaving M. do F^raudy sitting pecchless over the footlights.

div.head: THE STATE OF EGYPT
div.p: An Anglo-Egyptian correspondent in n letter to the Spectator' remarks:

The fallacious idea of the Britisher that what is best in his own country must be right everywhere runs through his administration of Egypt. For instance, nothing could be less necessary, or more disastrous, than to nllow a free Press in an Eastern country ; tho native press is tho sole cause of all tho ill-feeling which is now being aroused in Egypt, aud it is creating discontent in every town and village in the country. Again, tho English dislike of "outward show'' prevails, from Lord Cromer downwards, although one would have thought its utility almost an axiom in tho East. It* abscnco makes tlie uneducated native consider that the high English official Is of very little account, and prerents him identifying in any way tho good government of tho country with tho presence of the English. This ostrich-like attitude is.doubtless partly due to tho delight­ful theory so ^ong maintained that the Egyp­tian would bo able to govern himself in a very few years, and therefore must retain all the externals of power without it* realities. A very short residence in Egypt convinces poo that the fulfilment of this theory must wait for tho Greek Kalends. To it, moreover, is also due the fact that we are not doing ouraelves justice in the administration of the country, by not permitting a sufficient number of Englishmen to enter tho service to properly supervise each department. (This remark does not apply to the department of Irrigation or Public Itistruction).I feel I am on very danger oud ground when I deplore tho untimely aboli­tion of corporal punishment. Prisons on Euro pean lines, but without Europeans to see that really hard work is enforced, are quite useless 1 as a deterrent from crimo; and I confess that I think the application of corporal punishment 1 by older of a properly constituted Court of Law bears very little resemblance to its applica­tion in the bad old day* by overy Pasha who 1 came along."

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY
div.p: A meeting of the Municipal delegation was 1 leld yesterday afternoon under the presidency 1 if Schioos Pasha.

A letter was read from the Minister of the 1 interior authorizing the Municipality to pro- 1 ned immediately to tho demolition of the fort fications on (ho south of Port-Rosette and to ell tho stones thereof,. 50% going to the government
A letter was also read requesting the Mu- licipality to defer the question of the new heatre, and asking, at the samo time, fora flan of tho theatre and the site chosen.

Another letter from the Ministry of the interior was read informing tho Municipality hat tho Ministry is uuable to modify the xmdition* already granted for the concession >f lands at Moharrem Bey for the construction of workmen's house*

A proposal of the sanitary inspector was discussed relative to tho establishment of a antral market, which would be built at the lide of tho no te quay* when refrigerator* for the preservation of fish would be installed. The proposal was referred to the various ser­vice* and to the chief engineer, to be examined into at tlie tame time a* public markets in general.
Tho project for the reorganisation of the sanitary service was referred to the finance and health committees.
The Delegation decided to submit tho question of the continuation of the Mex line as for as Dekhela, to the Commission.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Council of Ministers at its last meeting approved of the rank of Mirmiran being conferred on Ahmed Bey Fathy Zaghloul, Under­secretary of State at the Ministry of Justice, Ahmed Bey Afifl, President of the Mixed Court of Appeal and Tabia Bey Ibrahim, President of the Native Court of Appeal.

The German Emperor has conferred the 3rd class Order of the Crown of Prussia on M. Gumprecht, German Consul, the 4th class Order of the Red Eagle on M. O. Mez, and the 4th class Order of the Crown of Prussia on Pastor Kahle
Sir Horace Pinching's successor is to be Dr. Graham Bey.
Carter Wilson Bey, Director of the Personal and Accounts of the Ministry of thq Interior has left Cairo for England on leave of three and a half months.
The nomination of Mr. George Vayssitto tho legion of Order will shortjy be announced in the Parisian "Journal Official."

div.head: ALEXANDRIA PATRIARCHATE
div.p: A question of considerable interest in regard to the jurisdicton of the Orthodox Patriarchate of Alexandria hsa lately been decided at Constantinople The Patriarch of Alexandria asked for a permit to visit the Greek communities in Tripoli of Barbary. The Sublime Ottoman Porte, however, has sent a note to the (Ecumenical Patriarchate to the effect that the Orthodox Communities in the Vilayet of Tripoli come within the province of the (Ecumenical Patriarch and not within the Patriarchate of Alexandria.

Mgr Porphyrios, the Archbishop of Mount Sinai, is desirons of removing his residence to Cairo and has asked the (Ecumenical Patriarch to use his good offices with the Patriarch of Alexandria for this purpose. Tbe Canon Law is against the Archbishop's tesidence being in a city under tbejnriadiotion of the Patriarchate of Alexandria The orthodox authorities of the Phanor have advised the Archbishop to come to an understanding with Pbotins I directly, and if he bo not suooessful to adress himself to the Patriarch of Jerusalem.

div.head: UPPER NILE SURVEY
div.p: Before the present summer sets in.sbont 750 kilometre of the preliminary levelling and surveying of the Nile Valley between Khartoum and Wady. Halfa will have been completed. As soon is this task is ended the cataract will be surveyed in detail in order to furnish the Ministry of Public Works with a series of accurate large scale maps of this port of the river valley.

div.head: UNITED EGYPTIAN LANDS, LTD
div.p: The connection of Mr. Charles Baco with the board of directors of the Company, is as a substitute on the board in the place of Mr. Sidney Carver daring that gentleman's absence from Egypt. Mr. Carver will be away for about two months and during that period Mr. Bacos will replace him temporarily as a director.

div.head: PEARL FISHING
div.p: The Sudan Government is engaged in inquiring into the possibility of developing the pearl fishery industry in the Red Sea. The service of Mr. Crassland, a well-known marine biologist, have been engaged for this purpose and he is constructing scientific investigations as to the influences affecting the Igo and con­ditions of existence of the pearl oyster. After a few years of preliminary work it will be decided how to exploit the industry commercially.

div.head:
FAMINE IN SAMARA.
7S0 000 PEOPLE STARVING.
URGENT NEED FOR HELP.

div.p: A letter from a commissioner of a benevolent society sent to investigate the ravages of famine, dated Samara 3rd April, says that 750,000 people are starving in Samara alone, of whom 373,000 arc receiving bare relief which must cease by 1st May unless fresh funds are forthcoming. The famine outside Samara is equally appalling. The writer main­tains that 20,000,000 people must perish unless fully £500,000 are forthcoming. (R.)

div.head:
DUMA AND THE BUDGET
STAND AGAINST GOVERNMENT.

div.p: It is understood that M. Galovin is taking a stand against the Government relative to the Duma's right to consult outside experts on the budget. An open conflict between the Duma and the Government therefore seems inevitable. (Reuter)

div.head:
CANADA AND AMERICA
QUESTION OF FISHING RIGHTS.

div.p: It is officially stated that a treaty has been drafted appointing a joint commission to consider all complex questions at issue between Canada and America concerning the water boundaries and fisheries. (Reuter)
Sir. Bryce, Earl-Grey, and Mr. Root have been discussing Canadian and American ijues tions but report that a treaty iv premature.(Reuter)

div.head:
DR. MAUCHAMP'S MURDER
SULTAN'S ANTI-EUROPEAN EDICT. .

div.p: A feeling of unrest prevails amongst Euro­peans at Fez owing to an anti-European edict of the Sultan expressing regret at the murder of Dr. Mauchamp but declaring that tho occu pation of Ujda was unjustifiable and contrary to the treaties, and hoping that it will be evacuated. (Reuter)

div.head:
KINGS EDWARD AND ALFONSO.
POLITICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF MEETING.

div.p: King Edward aud King Alphonso lunched on Board the Royal yacht with the Queen Mother. (Reuter)

The newspapers dwell on the political signi Acance of King Edward's visit to Cartagena in connection with Great Britain's ever increas­ing influence in thesettlenient of Mediterranean questions. (Reuter)
King Edward and King Alfonso have stated that the family bonds between the two nations affirm the relations of the two nations. (Havas)
The Kings of Italy and Greeqp have affirmed the friendship of the two nations. The Chamber of Deputies has sent an enthusiastic welcome to King Victor Emmanuel. (Havas)
The bakers have voted a general strike.
(Havas)

div.head:
THE THAW CASE.
COUNSEL'S ELOQUENT APPEAL.

div.p: Thaw's counsel thrilled the crowded court by his eloquent and telling address, enlisting the sympathies of tho jury on behalf of the avenger of his wifo's wrongs. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE TRAFALGAR ACCIDENT.
A MISUNDERSTOOD SIGNAL

div.p: The accident to the Trafalgar was due to a signal from the bridge being misunderstood. (Reuter)

div.head:
BANK OF ENGLAND.
NEW GOVERNOR APPOINTED.

div.p: Mr. William Campbell has been appointed Governor of the Bank of England, and 31 r. Edgar Lubbock Deputy Governor. (Reuter)

div.head: THE FAYOUM
div.p: REMARKABLE- DISCOVERIES.

Tho expedition of Professor Henry Osborn to the F*youm, in search of the extinct an­cestors of elephants, rhinoceroses and horses bos boon successful. Tho most remarkable of tho monsters unearthed by Professor Osborn is the arainijithorium, named in honor of the. Queen This animal had a huge pair of horns, projecting forward above tho nostrils and a ■mailer pair of horns lying farther back. Its nearest allies, strange to say, are tho extinct animals discovered in Wyoming and named the dinocoros, or amblypods, in sands haring tho some geological ago as those of Fayoum Although as large as tho arsioditherium, and some of them endowed with three pairs of horns, none had a front pair as large and singular a» those of the beast of Fayoum.

These specimens, so widely separated geo graphically, are considered os representatives of a great group of mammals which sprung from common ancestors. Tho huge horns of the arsinditherium, sot in a skull threo feet long, with powerful jaws two feet long, having a complete series of most remarkable teeth, emphasize tho present scientific view, that homs of animals were primarily not so much for defence as to enablo tho males to fight for supremacy in their own herds and lord it over the females.

Another extinct wonder which Profossor Osborn will take to America from Egypt is tho moritherium, somowhat smaller than the last, which is undoubtedly an elephant, yet with littlo resemblanco to one, as it was appar­ently trunkless and hod only small, toothlike tusks. That it was an elepliant at all is shown by tho teeth, undoubtely mastodonlike. This animal is regardod as closely related to tho ancestors of all elephants, if not the actual ancestor. From this piglike raeritherium surely sprang tho huge latter day elephant. The world was younger when the moritherium wjs evolved and animals were small. The ancestors of tho hugo dinosaurs were then Kttle lizards ; the ancestors of the horse wore no bigger than lambs, and the ancestors of rhinoceroses were not much larger than pigs.

Directly north of lake Karoun rising step above step like a great amphitheatre, are the terraces of the Fayoum desert, one thousand feet thick,-which culminate in tho pebbly sum­mit of the great Libyan desert. On one of these steps in 1902 members of the Geological Survey of Egypt made the important, in fact epoch-making, discovery of the ancient mam­malian life of Africa, hitherto entirely un­known. In successive years the Survey and the British Museum sent parties to this desert and unearthed proofs of a rich and fertile country which existed perhaps two millions of years ago, long before tho Nile vnlley rift was formed. In the tributary streams and rivers .coarse and fine sands were deposited, containing the honen of mo animals of the period. While tho graves of tire Pharaohs have been sacked for the last five thousand years, nature has concealed this burial tolace until the twentieth century. This was tMo nursery of Africa's distinctive contri­bution to the mammalian life of tho world, including so far as known at present the proboscides, or elephants; tho sirenia or tea cows, manatees, and dugongs ; tho hyraeoidoa, or rock and tree conies, tho zeuglodontia, or primitive whales. There were also the arsinoi- therea, great quadrupeds which never journey­ed beyond tho confines of Africa.

The peculiar interest of the American Museum iu this discovery lay in the fact that three of these groat groups subsequently found their way over to North America, namely, the elephants, sirenians, and zeuglodonts. In American collectitns they are richly repre­sented by highly developed «nd specialized but ancestorloasforms. It was obviously worths long and expensive journey to bring home these extremely ancient Egyptian ancestors and thus trace these animals buck to their beginnings in tho Eocene period, when.they were of small sjze. Prof. H. F. Osborn formed the plan and President Morris K. Jesup generously con­tributed the cjiief expenses of. tho expedition.
„ INTO THE DESERT.

Tho party, including - Professor Osborn and two nssi-fants, Walter Granger and' George Ol^cn, both#well trained in'Rocky Mountain exploration, left Ndw Yorlf'on January 5, and reached/ Caift) on .January 23f Liberally assisted bu the Egyptian Geological Survey, the Urge'camel efrayan |raa feulj; to start on January 29^ fully equipped jvith tents, tools, and especially with ttC fantqAtt,™ water tanka.
' tAe SITT^O^HE FINDS.

A permanent ^caftp was mado, overlooking the reins* oY thq, ancient city of Dirpeh, eight pniles to the south, with Birket el Kanffin beyond. Tho waters of this lake are i^irft^for either men or animals, and after exhausting some temporary r«in pools, which soon evaporated, the party was dependent upon a water supply\carried on a three or four-day juhrney by camel. Thus the water caravans were constantly moving forward and backward. At fiist there was difficulty in getting competent laborera ; but Dr. J.B. Qui- bell, who irin ehargo of the field explorations of the Cairo Museum and every season is em­ploying a large number of men who comedown the Nile from Kuft, near Luxor, kindly volun­teered to lend us twelve of his skilled exca­vators. These natives are iu demand all along tho river becauso they have received training from boyhood under Doctor W. Flinders Petrie, and especially in recent pears under Dr. Reissner, who is famou- u a 'disciplinarian. Tho swarthy men red boys of Kuft passed from arolueo- logy to paleontology in the most natural manner, and after two day last motion
treated the fragile remains of the diminu- tive/adaestreli sf^dknV With m- great ten­derness as if they were handling a mum­mified king or a sMIcute roll of papyrus.
PACKING THE1 FOSSILS.

While Mr. Granger and Mr. Olsen were educating the forc<r<rf-seventeen native* in the refined methods'of-work which1 are absolutely essential to success, Professor Osborn, accom­panied by Mr. Ferrer, made a thorough recon­naissance of ths whole fossil field, ■ distance east and- woat of about forty-five miles; in ordor todatersdne tho scope of the-'work and to decide upon what-love! to moke the principal attack.- After ted daye nf continuous eesrch in the quarries first opened, it became evident that the axpe^tion would -be successful not only in bringing back perfect remains of ' tho auimals already known, butin adding to this aocioat life of Egypt a - number of animals hitherto uuknown and ■ undiscovered.

The Museum camp i* now equipped for this month, end-aeDaclr of -Mayas the temperature will pesmit, with »• water omravaa of eight osrneU, and a force of-twenty - ewcavator* who will gain in efficiency, every day. As the boxes are filled they will be transported- dtrect*y( by "sliipn of the desert" to Oliizcb,-a distance of for­ty-five miloa. In theBusvey-boikdings they will be repacked for tbaatill more severe jolting of the journey to New York. In about a year from now we may expoct to see the remote and diminutive African ancestors of the elephants placed beside their towering American offspring ' in the halls of our Museum.

div.head: THE HEDJAZ RAILWAY
div.p: Interest in the Hedjoz Railway is daily increasing with tho natives and the native Press. A traveller on the line, after in , dulging in enthusiastic descriptions of the laud traversed by the line, and ex- , patiatiug on the great benefits, present and prospective, accruing from this enterprise, gives the following interesting facte. In Tebuk everything is so well organiled that you , imagine yourself at one of the best railway stations. Ahead of this place lies a beautiful valley spanned by massive bridges on which the railway runs. Two kilometers off this valley you can see the work named on with tho utmost, regularity, and the Imperial troops are building there a sort of a fort; whilst on kilo meter 730 they have raised a solid bridge with the following inscription ia, the middle thereof: "Memorial of the Hamidieb technical regimont 1324." Besides this the troops have built smaller bridges, and are about to complete a large one ; and all this they have accomplished with creditable skill and precision.

There are special trains for the transport of the material aud provision requisites of these troops, so that there may be no hindranoo to the progress of the work. The water supply is also very adequate, and the works beyond kilomoter 744, are being pushed with fair rapidity. The satisfaction of the people is uni- "enuil and great There ha,boon discovered in the vailey of Jeiba lying about three and half hours from Sidon, and within 10 kilomstara of Haiffa, a coal mine whiob is expected to prove very useful for thegrand Hedjat line, and I have further ascertained the existence of petroleum sources in the regions of the Hauran, which also will prove of no small benefit to this great Imperial enterprise. As regards the coal mine discovered in the dUtrict of A1 Keneitra, not being found utilizable it was filled up.

A Constantinople native contemporary also makes, among other commonplace remarks abo it the line, the following, which are not uninteresting : "Deraa is destined to become a ! fairwbereiaMjall be sold the products,—such ' as whes^ barley, dary raid Bosamesced— of Jebel Ajloun, Jebel Ed Berouz and the other1 fcrtil^ regions of the Hanran. ■

, Of special interest to the arobmologiat are the ruins 5ing between the sfiftions of Am- maanz Elffezira. This town in ruins the Arabs call El Ka|g, and it marks the site of the adcicnt cjtv of Philodo phia, the Vestiges of whose great temple and amphitheatre denote the grandeur and majesty, tl*t characterized the architecture of that epbch The walls of this city extend for about 'two"1 hours from North to South Thefcoil bcyojjd Moan, between Acre and Batn El Ght/nl is highly mineiatized, containing iron and oopper ore &nd borax The eirth of the region between the station of That al Haj and Bir Hermez is very salty. Indeed whole raounft of salt crystal are to be seen there. The Bedouins nay that those lands had been covered onoe with water, and that in a ro -Vv spot therein there is an unfailing sonree of pure water.

Six hours west of Hermez are to be seen; the ruins of Al Knreiba, the largest of tho seven towns thet had ..noe flourished in those parts. Indeed the walls of this town now jn ruins extend over a distance of five kilometers. Once a rivulet used to flow near by, and its * dry bed is still to be seen. Amongst those 1 ruins are to be found many stones with tho 1 pioture of men end lions, serpents and tigers 1 engraved tboreon, oo'pted somotime* with inscriptions, all of which point to tbo foot that a no mean order of civilization once flourished ' there. Not far from those parts it Jebel El Cha'ar from the midst of which rises a solitary summit which the- Prophet, with bis Asbaah, is said to have as^R'Isd. and prayed npon,1 accompanied by his Abyssynian M ienln Bela!, during the early part of the Jehad.

The climate In Tebuk is healthy, and the ■toil fertile, tho date tree being extensively cultivated rhera. In the neighbourhood of a ' village,1 of about 50 houses, there is the forepart of a ruined 'nroeqoo, wherein the Prophet is

said to have prayed, daring his early-religioos oatapaigB; Oh toe-same spot now a tnosquo -s being raised. All along we seothe Turk endeav­oring to exploit the religious feeliDg of the peep!-and make the most of it for the promo­tion of this arduous undertaking- So far despite the want of system and scientific organization it has progressed and gives the promise of ultimate fulfilment."

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Lieutenant A S Cooper, King's (VhScottish Borderers, on vacating the appointment of aide de camp to tho Reaident, Aden, has been posted to the 1st Battalion, Cairo
Captain D. Mathers, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniakilling Fusiliers, comes homo from Cairo to take up the appointment of adjutant of the Queen's Rifle Volunteer Brigade, Edinburgh.
Captain Wilson; Royal Army Medical Corps, on returning home from Egypt has been posted for duty to Belfast, where he joins next ^ week.

The War Office has unloosed its puree ' strings to the extent of granting £300 for two years out of the Army Funds to that most deserving of institutions, the Anglo-American Hospital at Cairo. The War Office could have gone much further without exceeding the claims of the Hospital.
A "Captain's Pocket Book" is'the latest outrage that the War Office* is meditating for the benefit of the company commander. The Army Council has called for suggestions for the book.
Lieutenant Murray, Coldstream Guards, has heon formally appointed aido dooamptoSir E.P Girouard, K C.M.G. tho new High Com­missioner for Northern' Nigeria

On the reduction of tho establishment of the West India Regiment, Captain G.W.8t G. Grogan, now attached to the Egyptian Army, has been transferred to the King's Own Light Infantry, in which ho wilt be borne as a supernumary Captain Grogan joined the West India Regiment in 1896, was promoted captain 1 1900, and served in tho operations in Sierra Leone, 1838 (medal with clasp); and in the Lagos Hinterland, 1898-99 (clasp) He took service with the Khedive's Army in 1902, and for some time lias been employed as an Inspect­or in the White Nile Province.
Gentleman Cadet H- Mayno, from tho Royal Military College, has been appointed to a second lieutenancy in the King's Own Scot­tish Borderers, and joins the home- battalion.
Captain N. R. Wilkinson, who commanded u company in the Coldstream Guards since 1899, and served with them in the inarch to Kira- borley, has gone on retired pay.

The impression is gaining ground that the Irish Guards are doomed if tho presont admin­istration remains in power long enough. Lord Roberts' hii\t to the effect that it might be the last time that he would present tho Queen's shamrock to them on St. Patrick's Day can be rend both ways.

Considerale comment has keen passed on the fact that Mr. Haldane finds no place in his scheme for (the thousands of ex-soldiers in the United Kingdom, and who, if properly organ­ised into regiments, batteries, and battalions, would form a very valuablo asset in home defence It may bo recalled that in tho dark days of the Boor war, the late Queen Victoria 1 appealed, to herold soldiers to.come forward, : and take the place of tho men who bad gone . to the front. The appeal was responded to * splendidly, and in a few weeks no fewer than ' eighteen battalions of veteran soldiers, inclod- inv a Guard's Reserve Battalion, were milled. Whilst conscription is not in lorce in the cd Kingdom, it has been calculated that one roan in every lour of the fighting populaoo has passed through tho army, navy, auxiliary, or other drilled forces. What material is going to loss for want of organisation!

It is announced that Sir Percy Scott, who is presently in the Mediteitanean experimenting with the latest thing in gunner)', will auooeed Rear Admiral Neville in tho command of | the First Cruiser Squadron.
The big battleship Dreadnought is to be 'one of the "lions" dicing the visit of the Colonial Premiers, and for that purpose will anchor in Portsmouth Harbour within easy reach of the Metropolis

The rosy official report on the Dreadnought is not-backed up by those who have ferved in her. It it unquestionable that the crew suffer considerable from the hear of machinery, and after all, seventeen knots in comfort is no great speed for a ship of her tonage. A Steady gun platform, she comes well up to the realisation of her obstructors

It is stated that the Hague Conference may not be owing to the disinclination of Germany, France, Austria, and Russia to disarm. If this be so, it will simplify Britain's ship building programme, and give no excuse to the Government to delay the building of the other Dreadnoughts.

The InterDepartmental Committed; which for the post year has been considering designs for quickfiring equipment for the Mountain Artillery batteries, have given orders fur two guns and two howitzer equipments on new designs for final approval. The new mountain the 2.95, which replaced thb old muule- ling "two point, five'' - underwent Its first test in the late Thibet operations, and did Nell, spitting Shells at the rate of Seven to eight per minute, with a range up to 4,000 yards. The old guns stood the test Of many years, poked their noses into many queer place* about the frontiers, and helped toextend die Empire When the tribesmen pin* for a ijttle excitement, no do bt our "Khurd Walihs" will be able to do the needful with the new gun the efficiency of which will bo assisted by the new equipment.

div.head: ADMIRAL'S WORDS CARRY WEIGHT

Ills statement concerning Pernna will have much weight a* It goes out Into the world.

div.p: Phillip Hitchborn, Rear-Admiral United States Navy, writes from Washington, D. C., as follows:
AFter the use of Peruna for a short period, I can now cheerfully recommend your valuable remedy to any one who is in need of an invigorating tonic."—Philip Hitchborn.

div.head: AN EVERPRESENT FOE
div.p: The soldier and the sailor are especially subject to constant change in some form or phase.

Exposed as they are to constant change subject as they are to various vicissitudes, and all kinds of climate, wet and dry, night and day, they find catarrh to be their most insidious and everpresent foe.
In the barracks and on the field, Peruna is equally efficacious.
Taken in time, it will absolutely prevent catching cold.

div.head: PE-RU-NA AN ABSOLUTE SPECIFIC
div.p: After a cold has become established, Pernna will break It up quicker than any other remedy known to man.
Kven afters cold has become tattled In some organ of the body Parana can be relied npon to promptly dispel it.
Parana will cure catarrh, whether acute or chronic, but a few doses taken in the first stage of the disease will be more effective than when the disease has become chronic.
It you suffer from catarrh in any form, do not neglect it. Take Peruna at once. Delays Delays in sucy matters are dangerous

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)
div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: ASSISTANT ENGINEERS.
The Municipality of Alexandria will proceed on June the 11th. next to appoint assistant engineers to tho following positions.

One temporary chief assistant'aiyd four temporary assistant engineers with experience of sewerage on a large scale : preference will be given to candidate* who liave hod experience of Sea-Outfall'jworks and pumping, and who havo a reccgnixod Civil Engineering diploma.
Salary of chief assistant engineer L.Eg.420 rising by biannual increments to L.Eg. 500, assistant engineer* L.Eg. 300 rising by bi­annual increments to L.Eg.360.
The appointments are guarranteed for five years if the candidates appointed prove satis­factory.
One permanent chief assistant and one permanent assistant Mechanical and Electri­cal Engineers.
Candidates must havo had thorough elec­trical training and experience.

They must have passed through the shops of a large' elqptrical works and must have experience in the. general arrangements aud design of central eloctrical stations, pumping plants on a Inrgo scale, and electrical distri­bution.
Preference will be given to candidates who hold a recognized Engineering diploma.
Salary of chief assistant engineer L.K. 420 rising by bi annual increments to L.E. 480, salary of assistant engineer L.E. 260 rising by bi annual increments to L.R 312.
One assistant' engineer with experience of road construction and maintenance.
Preference will be givon to those who have had experience in tho construction of tar maca­dam roads.
Salary L.E. 264 rising by bi-annual incre­ments to L.E. 312.
All applications addressed to me must reach tho Municipality not later than Thursday i June the 6th. j

Candidates must include in their applications | testimonials of training and experience, a testimonial of good conduct, a birth certificate and must undertake to obtain a colloquial knowledge of French in ono year.
Address
The Administrator The Municipality
Sig. W. P. Chatawat.
Alexandria—Egypt. 29976-3-1

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6. Purchasers should see that the word 'THERAPION' appears on British Government Stamp (in white letters on a red ground) affixed to every package by order of His Majesty's Hon. Commissioners, and without which it is a forgery.
